messages.content: What do you want to be when you grow up research

Got it, Bilal. Here’s a tight, research-backed cheat-sheet on “What do you want to be when you grow up?”—useful for workshops, surveys, and program design.

# What the research says (in 6 bites)

1) #Aspirations start early and narrow with age  
Kids build “maps” of acceptable jobs, then gradually **circumscribe** options (by gender/status) and later **compromise** when facing constraints. Start shaping images of work in primary school, not just high school. citeturn0search10turn0search0

2) #Aspirations cluster in a few “dream jobs,” often misaligned with labor demand  
By age 15, ~**47% of boys** and **53% of girls** expect one of just **10 jobs**; patterns have changed little since 2000 and often overlook growth fields. Visibility and guidance matter. citeturn1search7turn1search3

3) #Who you know (and what you see) matters  
Background, social capital, and exposure to real workers strongly shape goals—“you can’t be what you can’t see.” citeturn0search1turn0search16

4) #Motivation mechanics: SCCT + Possible Selves  
Interest and choices are driven by **self-efficacy**, **outcome expectations**, and **goals** (SCCT). Activities that help youth form vivid, feasible **possible selves** (who I could become / don’t want to become) raise engagement and persistence. citeturn0search18turn0search23turn0search24

5) #Stereotypes constrain who feels “invited”  
Classic DAST studies show how kids picture “a scientist” (lab coat, male, etc.). Representation is improving but stereotypes still rise through elementary/middle school—so role-model exposure is not cosmetic; it’s causal. citeturn1search0turn1search6

6) #STEM aspirations are stable without intervention  
Longitudinal ASPIRES (ages 10–23) shows early identities around science persist; family capital and school experiences steer trajectories. citeturn0search2turn0search12

---

# Design moves that work (actionable)

- **Multiple, authentic encounters** with workers (talks, site visits, mentoring). Frequency and authenticity beat one-off “career day.” Track who meets whom. citeturn0search16  
- **Possible-selves mapping**: short cycles where students sketch “hoped-for,” “expected,” and “feared” futures + “next small step.” Repeat each term. citeturn0search4  
- **Self-efficacy loops**: mini-projects that end with a public demo + micro-feedback from professionals (boosts perceived capability). citeturn0search18  
- **Stereotype countering**: use DAST-style prompts (“Draw a … in this field”) before/after role-model sessions to surface/shift images. citeturn1search0  
- **Reality checks without killing hope**: pair aspirations with 3 real job variants (core, adjacent, stepping-stone) + entry routes. Use local data when possible. citeturn0search16

---

# Quick instruments you can run next week

- **Mini-DAST/“Draw-a-Professional”** (10–15 min pre/post). Score with a short checklist (gender, tools, context) to make bias visible to learners. citeturn1search6  
- **Possible-Selves Cards**: 3 sticky notes—“Hoped-for self / Expected self / Feared self”—then a 2-week micro-goal linked to each. citeturn0search24  
- **SCCT Snapshot**: 6-item pulse on (a) confidence to do X, (b) belief it pays off, (c) concrete next goal—repeat monthly. citeturn0search18

---

# Program skeleton (60–90 minutes)

1) **Warm-up**: “Draw someone doing ___” (choose target sector). 8 minutes. citeturn1search0  
2) **Real humans**: 2 role models + Q&A focused on “first step I actually took.” 20 minutes. citeturn0search16  
3) **Possible-selves loop**: map hoped/expected/feared; pick one micro-action for this week. 20 minutes. citeturn0search4  
4) **Reality triad**: for each dream job, list **Core / Adjacent / Stepping-stone** roles + entry routes. 15 minutes. citeturn1search7  
5) **Re-draw + reflect**: what changed in your picture? 10 minutes. citeturn1search6

---

# If you want a short reading pack (start here)

- Gottfredson’s **Circumscription & Compromise** (how options narrow). citeturn0search10  
- OECD **Dream Jobs?** (PISA 2018: concentration in a few jobs; guidance gaps). citeturn1search7  
- Lent, Brown & Hackett’s **SCCT** overview. citeturn0search23  
- **ASPIRES** longitudinal reports (identity and science careers, 10–23). citeturn0search12

---

If you want, I can turn this into a one-page facilitator guide with prompts + a simple scoring sheet for DAST and Possible-Selves.
I heard there was a research that showed people want to be influencers can you help me find that

Yep—there are a few solid sources showing that a lot of young people aspire to be influencers/creators:

- **Morning Consult (U.S., 2023):** *“Roughly 3 in 5 Gen Zers (57%) said they would become an influencer if given the opportunity,”* virtually unchanged from 59% in 2019. citeturn2view0  
- **YouGov (U.S. teens 13–17, 2021):** The **top dream job overall** was **professional streamer** (11%); the piece discusses streamer/influencer/esports as new leading aspirations among teens. Sample: 3,670 teens. citeturn1view0  
- **LEGO global kids survey (8–12, US/UK/China, 2019):** Children were **3× more likely to say “YouTuber” (29%) than “astronaut” (11%)** when asked about dream jobs. citeturn0search14

If you tell me the age range and country you care about (e.g., MENA vs. U.S./EU), I can pull region-specific stats next.
